BRAZIL
: Rondonia .
62 km SW Ariquemes
, fzda. Rancho Grande ,
5-17-X-1993
, J.E. Eger , black light trap ( WOPC , 1)
.

Diagnosis. Members of this species are distinguished from superficially similar specimens of
P. catarina
by the shiny condition of their interstitial spaces.

Description. Size : Length 5.0 mm; width 1.5 mm . Form : As in Fig. 121 . Integument : Head mostly yellow, upper frons and epicranium black, antenna brown; pronotum black at disc and lower sides, remainder yellow; elytral disc brown, epipleural margin yellow; legs mostly yellow, profemora and tibiae infuscated; pterothorax, and abdomen black. Head : Eyes as wide as frons (12:12); funicular antennomeres slightly expanded, 6 th antennomere not acuminate ( Fig. 1 ). Thorax : Pronotum transverse (35:32), lateral tubercle moderately prominent ( Fig. 11 ); asetiferous punctures end at about distal elytral 4/5, epipleural fold gradually diminishing to elytral apex. Abdomen : Tegminal lobes and phallic apex as in Fig. 85 .
Variation. Size : Length 3.8–5.9 mm ; width 1.3–1.8 mm . The sutural margin may be yellow.

Natural History. Specimens were collected during May, August, October, and Novem- ber. Some specimens were taken with a blacklight trap in a slash/burn area or tropical transitional forest, at altitudes ranging from 300 to 1,769 m .
Distribution. Known from Bolivia and Brazil ( Fig. 125 ).
Etymology. The specific epithet is a patronym honoring Steven and Cathy Cassel, two of the nicest people I have ever known.
